`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.p,{children:["In the world of single-board computers (SBCs), there\u2019s an intriguing new player i.e the ",(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{href:"https://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/_DkuskjB",children:"Radxa X4"})," \u2014an Intel-based board that\u2019s almost the same size as a Raspberry Pi. Powered by the Intel N100 processor, this board packs an impressive punch, reaching speeds up to 3.4 GHz."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/intel-n100.webp",width:"1137",height:"784"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"Since it\u2019s built on x86 architecture, it offers broad compatibility with various Linux distributions and can even run Windows. With a full BIOS, users can modify settings just like on a traditional desktop. But the most surprising feature? It\u2019s nearly the same size as the Raspberry Pi 5, even fitting snugly into the official Pi 5 case, with just a slight overhang."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"Let\u2019s take a closer look at this board's performance and potential uses."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h2,{id:"technical-specifications",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#technical-specifications",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Technical Specifications"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(h,{}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h3,{id:"performance-on-windows-and-linux",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#performance-on-windows-and-linux",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Performance on Windows and Linux"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"First, I installed Windows 11 and drivers from Radxa\u2019s site. The setup ran smoothly, and general tasks performed well, giving a near-desktop experience. Streaming was also surprisingly fluid: Full HD YouTube videos played without a hitch, and even 4K videos streamed smoothly, with no dropped frames. Graphics-intensive tasks were similarly impressive on Windows."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"For instance, while running WebGL, the board maintained 60 frames per second (fps) with up to 10,000 elements, although it did drop at 15,000. Testing this on Ubuntu, I found that 5,000 elements held steady at 60 fps, with performance dipping at 10,000\u2014an indication that graphics rendering performs better on Windows."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/webgl.webp",width:"721",height:"495"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h3,{id:"pushing-the-cpu-thermal-performance-and-modifications",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#pushing-the-cpu-thermal-performance-and-modifications",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Pushing the CPU: Thermal Performance and Modifications"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"Next, I ran a CPU stress test with CPU-Z, and I noticed thermal throttling started at around 64\xB0C. The N100\u2019s thermal limit is 85\xB0C, so I adjusted the board\u2019s power limit in the BIOS from 6 watts to 12.5 watts. This helped delay throttling, although temperatures did continue to rise. Using Sysbench on Ubuntu, I saw similar results."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/cpu-temperatures.webp",width:"640",height:"429"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"To improve cooling, I swapped the thermal pad for a copper shim and thermal paste, then re-ran the stress test. This change made a significant difference: on Windows, the CPU stayed under 54\xB0C without throttling, and on Ubuntu, it remained below 48\xB0C."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/thermal-paste.webp",width:"720",height:"470"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h3,{id:"benchmarking-performance-geekbench-and-power-usage",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#benchmarking-performance-geekbench-and-power-usage",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Benchmarking Performance: Geekbench and Power Usage"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"In Geekbench tests, this board demonstrated impressive performance, scoring about 30% higher in single-core performance than both the Raspberry Pi 5 and the Orange Pi 5 Max. In multi-core tests, it outperformed the Raspberry Pi 5 by 60% and matched the Orange Pi 5 Max, which has eight cores."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/geekbench-comparison.webp",width:"2382",height:"1092"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"Interestingly, running Geekbench on Ubuntu gave slightly better results than on Windows. The board\u2019s power consumption maxed out around 18 watts during these benchmarks."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/geekbench-ubuntu.webp",width:"717",height:"514"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h3,{id:"storage-and-memory-testing",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#storage-and-memory-testing",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Storage and Memory Testing"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"When testing NVMe storage speeds, I achieved read and write speeds of 3200 MB/s on Windows, although speeds were slightly lower on Linux, at 2200 MB/s. This difference could be due to system optimizations, so I\u2019ll continue to investigate."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/nvme-performance.webp",width:"713",height:"557"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"The memory bandwidth test produced around 4800 MiB/s for memory copy and about 7000 MiB/s for block copy."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h3,{id:"real-world-applications-and-use-cases",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#real-world-applications-and-use-cases",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Real-World Applications and Use Cases"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"The board\u2019s capabilities make it ideal for various applications. For example, I set up Home Assistant for smart home automation, adding Whisper for speech-to-text and Piper for text-to-speech. Using the small-int8 model, Whisper translated commands in under 3 seconds\u2014faster than both the Orange Pi 5 Max (4.5 seconds) and Raspberry Pi 5 (14 seconds)."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(a,{alt:"radxa-x4",src:"/static/images/2024/radxa-x4-sbc/voice-assistant-performance.webp",width:"959",height:"598"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"At idle, the board consumes around 7 watts with the NVMe and fan running, which is manageable for always-on applications."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"Beyond home automation, the board\u2019s x86 architecture opens a range of possibilities:"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.ul,{children:[`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.li,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.strong,{children:"Network Attached Storage (NAS)"}),": Using OpenMediaVault, you can create a high-speed, low-cost NAS server."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.li,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.strong,{children:"Virtualization"}),": With Proxmox, the board can handle multiple virtual machines, offering a flexible testing or server environment."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.li,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.strong,{children:"Desktop Use"}),": It\u2019s suitable for general computing, web browsing, and light media consumption, with potential for light gaming."]}),`
`]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h3,{id:"some-limitations-to-consider",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#some-limitations-to-consider",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Some Limitations to Consider"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"While powerful, the board does come with a few caveats:"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.ol,{children:[`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.li,{children:[`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.p,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.strong,{children:"Higher Power Consumption"}),": The idle power usage (7-8 watts) is roughly double that of ARM-based SBCs like the Raspberry Pi 5, which idles around 3-4 watts. This extra power usage may impact users aiming for ultra-low-energy setups."]}),`
`]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.li,{children:[`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.p,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.strong,{children:"Memory Bus Limitation"}),": Due to its compact design, the board uses a 32-bit memory bus instead of the full 64-bit bus that LPDDR5 RAM can support. This limits the maximum potential memory bandwidth."]}),`
`]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.li,{children:[`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.p,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.strong,{children:"Non-Adjustable Fan"}),": The fan runs at full speed continuously, regardless of the board\u2019s temperature, which could affect noise levels in quieter setups."]}),`
`]}),`
`]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.h3,{id:"final-thoughts-and-pricing",children:[(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#final-thoughts-and-pricing",children:(0,e.jsx)(i.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Final Thoughts and Pricing"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.p,{children:["For around ",(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{href:"https://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/_DkuskjB",children:"\u20AC57 for the 4 GB RAM model and \u20AC75 for the 8 GB version"}),", this board is a competitive choice compared to the Raspberry Pi 5, especially considering its Intel-based x86 CPU. Radxa\u2019s upcoming X4L version is expected to add more features, which I\u2019ll cover in future reviews."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(i.p,{children:"This board is ideal for those looking for a flexible, powerful, and nearly pocket-sized x86 system. Its potential use cases\u2014from home automation to light desktop computing\u2014are broad, making it a strong alternative in the SBC market."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(i.p,{children:["If you enjoy my content and want to support the channel, consider ",(0,e.jsx)(i.a,{href:"https://buymeacoffee.com/amrutprabhu",children:"buying me a coffee"}),"."]}),`
